results.adx_keywords: Health Insurance and Managed Care;Doctors;Series;Surgery and Surgeons;Hospitals;Paying Till It Hurts (Series)
results.title: After Surgery, Surprise $117,000 Medical Bill From Doctor He Didn’t Know
results.abstract: In a growing practice, medical assistants, consultants and other hospital staffers, often called in without patients’ knowledge, are charging hefty fees.

media.caption: Peter Drier was billed by an assistant surgeon he did not know was on his case.
Peter Drier, a bank technology manager in New York City, was blindsided after neck surgery by a $117,000 bill from a doctor he did not recall meeting.
media.copyright: Joshua Bright for The New York Times

media.caption: Patricia Kaufman, at home in Highland Park, N.J., with her husband, Alan, was charged $250,000 by two plastic surgeons who sewed up an incision after her back surgery.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

media.caption: Insurers have gone to court with NeuroAxis Neurosurgical Associates, a private practice in Queens, over what they call excessive fees for surgical assistants.
media.copyright: Uli Seit for The New York Times

media.caption: Mark Sullivan, 46, of New Jersey, received a hospital bill that included charges for occupational therapy, which he did not realize had occurred.

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Obama, Barack;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;National Security Council;Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS);Rice, Susan E;Klain, Ronald A
results.byline: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MARK LANDLER
results.title: Amid Assurances on Ebola, Obama Is Said to Seethe
results.abstract: President Obama has assured the public that the government’s response was adequate. But he has also quietly faulted the handling as “not tight.”
org_facet: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
ISLAMIC STATE IN IRAQ AND SYRIA (ISIS)

media.caption: People briefed on a cabinet meeting said Mr. Obama was angry at the Ebola response.

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;Vinson, Amber Joy;Airlines and Airplanes;Duncan, Thomas Eric;Pham, Nina;Epidemics;Dallas (Tex);Texas;Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital;Nursing and Nurses
results.byline: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JACK HEALY
results.title: With New Ebola Case Confirmed, U.S. Vows Vigilance
results.abstract: The news that a second nurse was infected in Dallas and that she was cleared to fly the day before showing symptoms raised questions about officials’ ability to control the disease.
org_facet: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

media.caption: An ambulance on Wednesday took Amber Joy Vinson to the Dallas airport for transport to Emory University Hospital in Atlanta.
Workers also cordoned off Ms. Vinson's apartment.
media.copyright: Sana Syed/City of Dallas Public Information, via Associated Press

media.caption: In Washington, President Obama directed his aides to monitor the Ebola outbreak in a “more aggressive way.”

results.adx_keywords: Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Ferguson (Mo);Brown, Michael (1996-2014);Wilson, Darren (1986- )
results.byline: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, MATT APUZZO and JULIE BOSMAN
results.title: Police Officer in Ferguson Is Said to Recount a Struggle
results.abstract: The man who fatally shot a teenager in Missouri in August has told investigators that he feared for his life, according to officials.

media.caption: Investigators with Michael Brown’s body on Aug. 9.
Darren Wilson, the officer who shot Mr. Brown, at a City Council meeting in Ferguson, Mo., in February.
media.copyright: Uncredited/City of Ferguson, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Dallas (Tex);Texas;Duncan, Thomas Eric;Liberia
results.byline: By KEVIN SACK and MANNY FERNANDEZ
results.title: Delay in Dallas Ebola Cleanup as Workers Balk at Task
results.abstract: Local and federal health officials have displayed an uneven and often-flawed response to the first Ebola case diagnosed in the United States.

media.caption: Zachary Thompson and Christopher Perkins, Dallas County health officials, leaving the home where Thomas E. Duncan stayed.
The Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, where Thomas E. Duncan first sought treatment last week but was sent home.

results.adx_keywords: Obama, Barack;United States;Midterm Elections (2014);United States Politics and Government;Democratic Party
results.title: In This Election, Obama’s Party Benches Him
results.abstract: Democratic candidates — even those in states like Virginia that the president carried in 2008 and 2012 — do not want President Obama to campaign for them.

media.caption: President Obama headed to Marine One for fund-raising trips Tuesday to New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. There have been few campaign trips in 2014.
President Obama in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

results.adx_keywords: Water;Drought;Porterville (Calif);California;Tulare County (Calif)
results.title: With Dry Taps and Toilets, California Drought Turns Desperate
results.abstract: In Tulare County, hit hard by a relentless drought, daily routines have been upended by the drying of wells and the disappearance of tap water.

media.caption: Angelica Gallegos of Porterville, Calif., has not had running water for more than five months.
Fred Beltran, left, and Frankie Olmedo unloading drinking water and buckets in Porterville, Calif., where taps have grown dry and residents frustrated.
At a firehouse in Tulare County, Anthony Hernandez last month filled 55-gallon barrels with nonpotable water to be used for bathing, washing clothes and flushing toilets at his home.

results.adx_keywords: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships;Supreme Court (US);Indiana;Oklahoma;Utah;Wisconsin;Virginia
results.title: Supreme Court Delivers Tacit Win to Gay Marriage
results.abstract: The Supreme Court let stand appeals court rulings allowing same-sex marriage in five states in a move that may signal the inevitability of a nationwide right to such unions.
des_facet: SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, CIVIL UNIONS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS

media.caption: Tammy and Sylvia Torres wed in Fredericksburg, Va., as marriages began in five states.
media.copyright: Reza A. Marvashti/The Free Lance-Star, via Associated Press

media.caption: Protesters outside the Supreme Court. Opponents of same-sex marriage expressed frustration.

results.adx_keywords: Holder, Eric H Jr;Justice Department;Attorneys General;United States Politics and Government;Obama, Barack
results.title: Eric Holder Resigns, Setting Up Fight Over Successor
results.abstract: Replacing the U.S. Attorney General, who provoked the ire of Republicans as President Obama’s chief liberal warrior, could be a political nightmare.

media.caption: President Obama after announcing Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s resignation.
Possible successors include, from left: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former White House counsel; Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts; and Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr.

Other potential candidates include, from left, former Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm of Michigan; Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island; and two United States attorneys, Preet Bharara of New York and Loretta E. Lynch of Brooklyn.

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital;Dallas (Tex);Nursing and Nurses;Tests (Medical);Epidemics
results.title: 2nd Ebola Case in U.S. Stokes Fears of Health Care Workers
results.abstract: Officials were trying to figure out how a nurse who had treated Thomas Eric Duncan became infected despite wearing protective gear, as news of the new infection stoked the fears of health care workers across the country.

media.caption: A hazardous-materials crew on Sunday cleaned outside the Dallas apartment building of a nurse who was infected with Ebola.
Mayor Mike Rawlings spoke to residents of the street.
In response to the latest report of the second victim in Dallas, officials moved swiftly to clean and decontaminate many places where the nurse had been.
media.copyright: Cooper Neill for The New York Times

media.caption: Debra Buccellato, an emergency room nurse in Santa Rosa, Calif., said she had not undergone any active training for Ebola.
media.copyright: Jason Henry for The New York Times

media.caption: The authorities distributed informational fliers.
media.copyright: Louis Deluca/The Dallas Morning News, via Associated Press

media.caption: A police officer provided security on Sunday at the Dallas residence of a nurse who had contracted Ebola. A barrel, left, held hazardous materials from a cleanup.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Rosenberg, Ethel;Rosenberg, Julius;Espionage and Intelligence Services;Cold War Era;Greenglass, David
results.title: David Greenglass, the Brother Who Doomed Ethel Rosenberg, Dies at 92
results.abstract: Mr. Greenglass, whose testimony against his sister and brother-in-law, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, in a 1951 spy trial helped send them to the electric chair, later admitted to lying.

media.caption: David Greenglass at a Senate Internal Security subcommittee hearing about American spying activities in April 1956.
Mr. Greenglass, with his sister, Ethel Rosenberg.
Ruth Greenglass, wife of Mr. Greenglass, in 1951. She had a supporting role in the conspiracy and gave damning testimony against the Rosenbergs. She died in 2008.
Mr. Greenglass, left, with a United States marshal in 1950.
Ethel Greenglass Rosenberg and her brother, David Greenglass, outside their childhood home.

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Dallas (Tex);Duncan, Thomas Eric;Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital;Liberia;Epidemics;Monrovia (Liberia)
results.byline: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and DAVE PHILIPPS
results.title: Death of Thomas Eric Duncan in Dallas Fuels Alarm Over Ebola
results.abstract: Mr. Duncan’s death renewed questions about health officials’ preparedness to contain Ebola. Hours after, hospital officials said a second patient had been admitted in Dallas.

media.caption: Sgt. Michael Monnig of the Dallas County sheriff’s office was taken to a hospital Wednesday and monitored for Ebola exposure.
Thomas Eric Duncan, 42, the Liberian man who was the first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States.
Saymendy Lloyd at a memorial service for Mr. Duncan at Wilshire Baptist Church in Dallas.
media.copyright: Cooper Neill for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Rockefeller Foundation;Global Warming;Philanthropy;Greenhouse Gas Emissions;Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline;Stocks and Bonds;Endowments;Colleges and Universities
results.title: Rockefellers, Heirs to an Oil Fortune, Will Divest Charity of Fossil Fuels
results.abstract: The family whose legendary wealth flowed from Standard Oil is planning to rid its $860 million Rockefeller Brothers Fund of investments in companies trading in nonrenewable energy.

media.caption: Stephen Heintz, left, with Valerie Rockefeller Wayne and Steven Rockefeller on Tuesday.

results.adx_keywords: Clinton, Chelsea;Clinton, Hillary Rodham;Clinton, Bill;Mezvinsky, Marc;Mezvinsky, Charlotte Clinton
results.byline: By AMY CHOZICK and NICHOLAS KULISH
results.title: Daughter for Chelsea Clinton (and Granddaughter for a Certain Couple)
results.abstract: The child, Charlotte, whose birth was announced on Twitter early Saturday, is the first for Ms. Clinton and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky.

media.caption: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton with their granddaughter, Charlotte Clinton Mezvinsky.
Chelsea Clinton and Marc Mezvinsky with their daughter, Charlotte Clinton Mezvinsky.
Chelsea Clinton earlier this month. The baby was born on Friday, according to a Clinton spokesman.

results.adx_keywords: White House Building (Washington, DC);Secret Service;Gonzalez, Omar J (1972- )
results.byline: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
results.title: Armed Intruder at White House Got to East Room
results.abstract: The man who jumped the White House fence made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent before he was tackled, a member of Congress said.

media.caption: Omar J. Gonzalez, who jumped the White House fence this month, reportedly got as far as the entrance to the Green Room before being stopped.

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Dallas (Tex);Frontier Airlines Inc;Duncan, Thomas Eric;Airlines and Airplanes;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
results.title: Ebola-Infected Health Worker in Dallas Took a Flight on Monday
results.abstract: The head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the worker, who had cared for a Liberian patient and contracted the disease, should not have been allowed on a commercial airline.
org_facet: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

media.caption: Dallas fire rescue workers wearing protective gear on Wednesday taped off a door at the Village Bend East apartments, where a second health care worker who has tested positive for Ebola lives.
media.copyright: Sana Syed/City of Dallas Public Information, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Ebola Virus;Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital;Hospitals;Cruises
results.byline: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and MITCH SMITH
results.title: Obama Names Democratic Operative to Coordinate Ebola Response
results.abstract: The appointment of Ron Klain, a White House veteran, spoke of the seriousness of the situation for the administration, which hoped to put the management of the crisis back on track.

media.caption: In Belton, Tex., on Friday, environmental workers prepared to disinfect North Belton Middle School, which had been closed because of the Ebola scare.
media.copyright: Rusty Schramm/The Temple Daily Telegram, via Associated Press

media.caption: A ship carrying a hospital worker who had handled Ebola specimens was returning to Texas.

results.adx_keywords: Republican Governors Assn;Lobbying and Lobbyists;Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington;Campaign Finance;Governors (US);Nonprofit Organizations;Republican Party;Republican Governors Public Policy Committee
results.title: G.O.P. Error Reveals Donors and the Price of Access
results.abstract: An unintended disclosure of documents from the Republican Governors Association opens a window onto corporate donors and the size of their checks.
org_facet: CITIZENS FOR RESPONSIBILITY AND ETHICS IN WASHINGTON

media.caption: Access to governors was one of many benefits for donors at the Republican Governors Association’s 2012 conference in Las Vegas.
Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana was at a 2011 donor event.
Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was at the event, in Washington.
media.copyright: Ricardo B. Brazziell/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Ohio;Kasich, John R;FitzGerald, Ed (1968- );Elections, Governors;Democratic Party;Republican Party;Midterm Elections (2014)
results.title: Fumbled Bid for Governor Imperils Ohio Democrats
results.abstract: Democrats had hoped a rousing fight in 2014 would energize the party’s grass roots and carry into the next presidential contest. Instead, they are facing a shutout in statewide races.

media.caption: Ed FitzGerald, the Democratic candidate for governor in Ohio, at Blind Bob’s, a bar in Dayton. He trails the incumbent  John Kasich in the polls.
media.copyright: Ty William Wright for The New York Times

media.caption: A Democratic supporter in Dayton backed candidates up and down the ticket. Democrats had hoped the  governor’s race  would energize the party.
media.copyright: Ty William Wright for The New York Times

results.byline: By WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER
results.title: U.S. Ramping Up Major Renewal in Nuclear Arms
results.abstract: An expansion comes under a president who campaigned for “a nuclear-free world” and made disarmament a main goal of American defense policy.
des_facet: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

media.caption: President Obama and Dmitri A. Medvedev, then the Russian president, in 2009 at the Kremlin in Moscow, where they signed an agreement to cut strategic nuclear arms.
The new National Security Campus in Kansas City, Mo.
Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.
The Y-12 National Security Complex in Oak Ridge, Tenn.
media.copyright: National Nuclear Security Administration, via Reuters
